awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Origin and Role of Dense Molecular Gas in Star-Forming Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
The team will use the Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope (GBT) to observe the dense gas in nearby galaxies.  The team has added a cutting-edge instrument, Argus, to this NSF facility.  This has paved the way for these important observations at millimeter wavelengths.  The team will study how galaxies form stars in their dense gas.  They will compare their observations to theoretical models.  Senior team members will train junior members recruited from underrepresented groups.  The team will feature the research in materials for the Bay Area Science Festival in California and the Green Bank Visitors Center in West Virginia.  The team will also help others use Argus for their own research.

The team will use Argus on the GBT to map the dense molecular gas in nearby galaxies at high spatial resolution.  They will combine these new data with existing data at other wavelengths to study (1) how the amount of star formation per unit of dense gas depends on the local conditions in the galaxies, and (2) how the amount of dense gas depends on the local conditions in the galaxies.

por.por_cntn:
The vast majority of the material world that we interact with on a daily basis was formed in the cores of an early generation of stars. While there are a few important exceptions, including the hydrogen in the water we drink and the lithium that is pervasive in batteries, we owe the bulk of our existence to this ‘star dust’. If we want to have a complete picture of where we came from, it is of paramount importance to understand where this star dust came from and hence how stars form. Over the last couple of decades, astronomical observations have shown that cold, dense molecular gas is an important ingredient in the star formation process.

 

The major goals of the Dense Extragalactic GBT+Argus Survey (DEGAS) project are to generate spectroscopic mapping surveys of a large number of northern galaxies in the Spitzer Infrared Nearby Galaxy Survey. These surveys mapped a number of different molecular species, including 13CO, C18O, HCO+, and HCN, to investigate the role of gas density in star formation. The particular goals of the project include understanding how physical conditions within the molecular gas depend on local parameters and galaxy scale processes and also include understanding how star formation relates to dense gas over a wide range of environments and a large, statistically significant area.

 

The DEGAS project coupled two state of the art instruments, the 16 element Argus spectrometer array and the Green Bank Telescope (GBT) – the world’s largest steerable telescope, to make exquisite maps of 17 galaxies at four frequencies near 100 GHz (wavelengths near 3 mm) corresponding to the emission lines of the above molecules. Even though these molecules are found in very cold regions of space (20 K), they can be excited by the ambient radiation field causing the molecules to rotate faster. When the molecules subsequently transition into a lower energy state, the transition involves the emission of electromagnetic radiation with a wavelength near 3 mm.  The Argus spectrometer array is specially designed to detect these (and other) transitions from molecules in interstellar space.  Similarly, the GBT is specially designed to collect as much of this radiation as possible and focus it to the Argus receiver in a way that allows us to observe these particularly faint lines with excellent (10 arcsec) resolution and high sensitivity. When these two instruments are combined, it enables the efficient spectroscopic mapping of the galactic environs in a large number of nearby galaxies.

 

Previous studies using ALMA have involved very high angular resolution maps of the very centers of galaxies, while lower resolution surveys (e.g. EMPIRE) have included the whole disk of a given galaxy in a single measurement. The DEGAS survey hits a sweet spot in angular resolution (10”) that allows the efficient mapping of the whole the galaxy (typically a 2’x2’ map) at the necessary angular resolution that can identify structures within the disk.  The previous surveys have shown that the dense gas fraction correlates with stellar mass surface density while the dense gas star formation efficiency anti-correlates with stellar mass surface density.  The preliminary DEGAS results corroborate these earlier findings; however, the DEGAS results at present suggest more scatter among galaxies.  The cause of this scatter is currently being investigated.  We anticipate to publish the first data release from DEGAS in early 2022.
